description: Inherited from Middle English rubben; possibly ultimately from Proto-Germanic *rubbōną, related to *reufaną (“to tear”).

Cognate with Saterland Frisian rubje (“to rub, scrape”), German Low German rubben (“to rub”), Low German rubblig (“rough, uneven”), Dutch robben, rubben (“to rub smooth; scrape; scrub”), Danish rubbe (“to rub, scrub”), Icelandic and Norwegian rubba (“to scrape”).
More at reave.

examples: Give that lamp a good rub and see if any genies come out.

entries.meaning: In the game of crown green bowls, any obstacle by which a bowl is diverted from its normal course.

definitionGroups.group: Any substance designed to be applied by rubbing.

entries.meaning: A mixture of spices applied to meat before it is barbecued.

verbs.description: rub (third-person singular simple present rubs, present participle rubbing, simple past and past participle rubbed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move (one object) while maintaining contact with another object over some area, with pressure and friction.
examples: I rubbed the cloth over the glass.
The cat rubbed itself against my leg.
I rubbed my hands together for warmth.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To rub something against (a second thing).
examples: I rubbed the glass with the cloth.
My shoes are beginning to rub.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To spread a substance thinly over; to smear.
examples: meat rubbed with spices before barbecuing

entries.meaning: (dated) To move or pass with difficulty.
examples: to rub through woods, as huntsmen

entries.meaning: To scour; to burnish; to polish; to brighten; to cleanse; often with up or over.
To hinder; to cross; to thwart.
(transitive, bowls) To touch the jack with the bowl.
